column3: 1934) was a Brazilian writer and politician. He founded and occupied the second chair of the Brazilian Academy of Letters
column4: from 1897 until his death in 1934. He was also the president of the aforementioned Academy in 1926.

column1: Coelho Neto was born in the city of Caxias
column5: and his mother was an indigenous woman
column6: Ana Silvestre Coelho.  At six years of age
column7: his parents moved to Rio de Janeiro. He began his education at the Externato of the Colegio Pedro II. He attempted medical school but soon gave up. In 1883 he enrolled at the University of São Paulo School of Law
column8: living in the boarding house where also lived Raul Pompeia
column9: who attended the Academy of São Paulo at that time. He soon found himself involved in a student movement against a professor. In anticipation of reprisals
column10: he moved to the Law Faculty of Recife
column11: where he completed the first year of law
column12: having been a student of the jurist and poet Tobias Barreto. Returning to São Paulo
column13: he devoted himself passionately to the abolitionist and Republican campaign
column14: an attitude that led to new frictions with the University of São Paulo School of Law. In 1885 he finally abandoned his legal studies and moved to Rio de Janeiro.

column1: He became part of a group of bohemians that included figures such as Olavo Bilac
column3: Guimarães Passos and Francisco de Paula Ney. The history of this generation appears later in his novels A Conquista and Fogo Fátuo
column4: dedicated to his friend Francisco de Paula Ney
column5: a brilliant orator and journalist known for his bohemian life style and his famous anecdotes. He joined the newspaper Gazeta da Tarde
column6: later moving to the sheet Cidade do Rio
column7: where he held the position of secretary. From this period date his first published volumes.

column3: daughter of educator Alberto Olympio Brandão. They had 14 children. One of those was the famous football player João Coelho Neto (known as "Preguinho").

column1: He was appointed to the post of secretary of the government of the state of Rio de Janeiro and the following year
column2: director of State Affairs. In 1892 he was appointed professor of art history at the Escola Nacional de Belas Artes (National School of Fine Arts) and
column4: professor of literature at the Colégio Pedro II. Author of numerous books
column7: he was appointed professor of history of theater and dramatic literature at the Escola de Arte Dramática (Drama School) in 1910
column8: and soon after director of the same institution.

column1: He was elected congressman for Maranhão in 1909 and was reelected in 1917. He was also secretary-general of the League of National Defense and a member of the Advisory Board of the Municipal Theater of Rio de Janeiro.
In addition to holding public office
column2: Coelho Neto maintained and intensified his activities in magazines and newspapers of all sizes
column3: in Rio and other cities. In addition to signing works with his own name
delivering a speech about his adoption of the spiritual doctrine in the Salão da Velha Guarda (Hall of the Old Guard) in Rio de Janeiro.

column1: He was active in virtually all literary genres and was for many years the most widely read writer in Brazil.  He wrote what could have been the first Brazilian serial movie
column2: The Mysteries of Rio de Janeiro.  However
column3: only the first episode was ever completed.

column1: He was probably the most widely read Brazilian writer in the first decades of the twentieth century.  However
column2: he and his work were attacked by the Modernists during the Modern Art Week (or Semana de Arte Moderna
column3: in Portuguese) in 1922 and this probably contributed to his later neglect by publishers and the Brazilian public.
